messages: 105bbb3c1ce4cdd44a2521c19ab5f155 (06:40): CSS animations aren't really appropriate for interactive animations, are they?
105bbb3c1ce4cdd44a2521c19ab5f155 (06:41): (By "CSS animation," I am referring to (https://developer.mozilla.org/en/CSS/CSS_animations>)
c41d451ed773297423055eb1b05dcbd2 (06:41): canvas might be better for that
105bbb3c1ce4cdd44a2521c19ab5f155 (06:41): I'm just playing around and don't have a real goal, so I'm not sure.
105bbb3c1ce4cdd44a2521c19ab5f155 (06:42): c41d451ed773297423055eb1b05dcbd2: That's kinda what I was thinking.  Or SVG.
c41d451ed773297423055eb1b05dcbd2 (06:42): if you want to do something interactive i'm guessing canvas would be better because of the sscripting api
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:46): I think CSS animations are for simple things, like mouse overs, and to assist Javascript in most needs of UI interaction.
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:47): So, if you want a nice animation after an ajax call, CSS animations are great.
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:49): Page transitions, more interactive forms... there is a great playground around that
105bbb3c1ce4cdd44a2521c19ab5f155 (06:49): 6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4: Ah, so I *can* trigger a CSS animation after a JS function call.  How the heck to I do that?
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:49): It's simple
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:50): First you make too classes for the start and final state
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:51): .loading {height:20px;background-image:url(l.gif);} and .loaded {height:auto;background-image:none;} would do.
105bbb3c1ce4cdd44a2521c19ab5f155 (06:51): 6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4: And use JS to change the class from "loading" to "loaded"?
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:51): via javascript is trivial to set this classes, right?
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:51): so you tell css to animate thease changes:
105bbb3c1ce4cdd44a2521c19ab5f155 (06:51): Ah, now *this* is where I got lost, I think.
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:53): .box {transition: height 800ms;}
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:54): sorry for the delay, I was checking the syntax
105bbb3c1ce4cdd44a2521c19ab5f155 (06:54): Why .box?
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:54): its a class that don't change along the process...
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:55): <div class="box"></div> on page load, then you trigger your ajax and set the class <div class="box loading"></div>
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:55): and finally wen content loads <div class="box loaded">content here</div>
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:56): just an example
105bbb3c1ce4cdd44a2521c19ab5f155 (06:57): And the engine knows to apply the transition style after code changes the class?
105bbb3c1ce4cdd44a2521c19ab5f155 (06:57): Thanks!

6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:58): the box {transition: height 800ms;} tells the engine that whatever happens to the height of the elements with a box class, instead of changing immediately, should change by transition
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:58): you can have many properties like opacity, width, height, and so on and on...
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:59): you can box {transition: all 800ms;} and change many properties at once
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:59): Here is a great example: http://hakim.se/inc/components/slideshow/#/
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (06:59): in firefox, just opacity animates, but when you open this one in Safari you will go "WOOOWW"
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (07:00): because Safari has a lot of 3D CSS transitions that firefox have not implemented yet
6ddf9b6f15e2de705e2438d7566784d4 (07:03): this one (only safari too) is really impressive http://m.madebycanvas.com/
105bbb3c1ce4cdd44a2521c19ab5f155 (07:08): Too bad Safari doesn't run on my system. :P
